Do you want to talk a little bit about what that was like?
Who do you live with?
I live with my parents and sisters.
So being home all the time was quite different to start with.
It meant I was doing less.
I was having less interactions with other people because of the fact that I didn't tend to keep in contact with other people.
I didn't keep in contact with many people personally anyway.
Before all this, the only connections that I had with people was when I actually saw them in the places where I went to.
I didn't really keep in contact with many people personally.
So it meant that I had less exercise and less people to talk to.
I started doing more exercise through it.
To start with that, that was quite strange being outside again after being inside for so long.
But sometimes when I do something that I've not done for a while, it's new again.
When I started back up kayaking in the new club after the old club lost its funding, it was new to me.
Then I struggled on the white water for a bit.
But then once I started walking and exercising more, I became fitter and started coping with it better.
But sometimes when I've been walking, the physical side of it, during lockdown, it's made me feel stronger.
Doing that distance wouldn't have made me stronger before because I'm not used to doing that distance.
So what kind of exercise were you doing then?
Just walking.
And were you doing that with anyone or just by yourself?
Just by myself, with my dad sometimes.
How many sisters do you have?
Two.
And are they older or younger than you?
One is older and the other is younger.
And do you get on with your sisters?
Yes.
And how was it being with them?
Did you do anything with them or how were they during that time at the beginning?
We sometimes watched telly together.
I was home with my younger sister a lot.
My older sister supported children of key workers so she wasn't home as often.
But she was still home a lot.
We were all still home a lot.
Most of the time the five of us were in the house.
So we spent more time with each other in that way.
And what was that like?
It was different. It was nice.
And did you find it different with your parents?
Did it feel different during that period than normal?
It was different being home for that length of time.
Sometimes it was a problem for me not to be doing anything for so long
because it's hard to get back into the routine of things when I'm not used to being committed.
Like I had to be before.
So you stopped work back in March. Were you furloughed then?
Yes, I was furloughed.
And how did that feel then when that first happened?
Well, it was something new.
I suppose it was a good thing that I wasn't losing money.
So I was still having some money even though I couldn't work.
It felt different not being in work.
In what way different?
I didn't see as many people. I didn't have to get up as early.
I didn't have to do as much work.
I didn't. In some ways I wasn't motivated as much as I had to be when I worked.
Sometimes I thought I learned new things.
Using online video calling was a new learning curve during lockdown
because that was not something that I did before then.
I'd never used Zoom or Teams before Covid.
I had a webcam but I'd never actually used it for video calling.
I'd only used it for taking photographs.
So that was quite exciting, quite difficult to start with.
I was worried about not being able to log into a meeting and how that technology works.
But I got used to that.
Did anyone help you with that or did you just have to figure it out yourself?
Well, my parents helped me.
I worked out that some laptops in the house work better than others.
But now I just use my desktop.
That works fine for me.
I'm more comfortable using a desktop than a laptop anyway.
Now that I'm used to it, I don't tend to have problems with it.
So you used it for your Mencap job.
Are there any other times that you used Zoom or Teams at all?
I used it with the Engage to Change project because I was one of the ambassadors.
Of course, that project had to stop as well because we couldn't go to different venues
with big groups of people in a conference to talk about the project and things like that.
But sometimes we had video calls to ask how we were and things like that.
And how was that?
That was the first time when I started using Zoom.
When I was with that project, it was quite stressful learning to use Zoom.
But once I got the hang of using Zoom and I got used to using it in Teams and all that, it was fine.
Difficult learning to use it to start with, but fine after I'd learned to use it.
So you managed to stay in contact with people a little bit through work,
but did you have any Zoom calls or anything just for social things with anybody?
Or was it just for Engage to Change and with your job at Mencap?
I was learning Disability Wales as well because I do some unpaid work on their trustee board.
So I had some Zoom video calls with them as well.
So you're asking about the social side of using Zoom in Teams.
Yeah, whether you used either of them to stay in touch with friends or with anybody outside of work.
I used Skype to contact my friend from around the corner,
who I've been in contact with since our early years on the high school minibus.
So we used to Skype each other a lot at one point.
And that was nice in a way, but different because we could stay up late and do it,
and I didn't have to get up for work.
I mean, it was different for him because he still worked as one of the key workers,
but I still had contact with him, with other people.
So there were a couple of other things that I used to do that I started with other people during lockdown.
One was when my phone started coming up with friend suggestions on social media
for people who I might know or might know people who I know.
Some of them were people who I didn't know to start with,
but at one point it came up with the daughter of the manager who took me on as a volunteer in my local community centre.
So I got in contact with her and asked how they were, and she asked how we were.
We asked how each other's families were basically.
So I spoke about not having contact with as many people and she suggested that I join the church group.
So to start with we did video calls and that was new to me because—
So with the whole group was that or just with her?
With the whole group. How many people were in the group would vary
because sometimes some of the groups were with people just around our age.
Sometimes they were with ranges of people to people our age, to people in their 50s, 60s, but it was with a group.
To start with, I think by that time I'd learnt to use Zoom on my desktop and I was okay with using it,
but it was difficult for me to start with because although I'd been in contact with the building since I was about 12,
my mum used to take me and my sisters when we were 12, and I did a bit of volunteering there since I was 18.
I've not been as heavily involved within the church group,
so most of the people who already knew each other there didn't know me as well as they knew each other,
and that was difficult to start with, especially as I didn't understand the sessions and terminology as well as they all did,
and sometimes it was embarrassing for me to admit that.
But it was good to start talking to them.
It was a bit frightening the first or second or so because I logged into a Teams meeting and I didn't know one person there,
but there were about two or three people who I familiarised myself with.
I went to the cinema with the group at one point.
So there were things like when the restrictions started to be lifted,
we could go for walks around Castle Cork and around Rother Park and different places,
so I did a couple of those walks in Cervinon Park.
But then after that I tried to get in contact with some of the other people in the group around my age.
Basically, I played tennis with three other people around my age to start at one point,
and I found that I struggled with the sport because I always struggled with that kind of sport.
We went to the cinema.
I went for a walk around the barrage in Cardiff Bay with two other people within the group,
and around the fields and things by where I live.
I've met someone within the group who I met through joining them during lockdown,
who I've met up with on a couple of occasions,
and I'm starting to get used to seeing people who I didn't know when I first met them.
So would you consider that person a friend?
I suppose it's difficult to say because when you're with groups of people,
you don't know whether they're there just for the group for you.
You don't know whether they see you as a friend in that group
or whether they see you as a friend or someone they have contact with.
But then there's things like how many people you're supposed to meet anyway,
and it's difficult to meet up indoors at the moment anyway.
I think yes, but I'm not entirely sure.
So how have you been in touch with this person?
How have you arranged when it's just been the two of you?
Through social media and the WhatsApp group that I was added onto,
and through texting.
Sometimes we go for walks together.
Just the two of you or with a bigger group?
Sometimes with the two of us, sometimes with three of us or four of us or five of us.
I think sometimes with groups, with organised groups,
it's harder to tell whether they're friends or not, whether they're your friends or not.
It's helped me in some ways.
Another, there was something else that I did as well.
So I got in contact with someone who I went to college with on my second year on social media,
and I asked her if she wanted to start meeting up again.
I said I was thinking of meeting up with more friends after the restrictions were starting,
during that time when the restrictions were starting to wheeze a bit,
and you could start meeting people in groups again.
I met up with her about three times, along with some of her other friends.
One of her closer friends was someone who I had a strong memory towards on the Play Our Way project,
and it was nice seeing him again, and we met up with each other about two or three times
in between August and September.
I don't seem to have much contact with them at the moment, but I did at that point.
So were they people you saw before lockdown or just people you reconnected with?
They were just people who I reconnected with.
And that was just through Facebook?
Yes, just through Facebook. I asked her if she wanted to start meeting up,
and she said yes, and she was meeting up with other friends on that day that I asked if she wanted to meet up,
so she invited me with them.
Sometimes as I get older it's harder to get people to want to meet up with me, but it's...
So it sounds like during that period that we had fewer restrictions, like you were out and about quite a bit?
Yeah, so I was out quite a bit while the restrictions were eased off a bit.
So how are things now then that people are coming out less and you're less able to meet?
Well, I think it's harder now with the restrictions tightening again, but I haven't met up with as many people now.
Have you still seen some people?
Sometimes I've seen people through the local church group, yes.
And the church hasn't been meeting inside at all during this time, during the previous time?
We started meeting inside during September.
And then has that stopped now then?
We still...
I think it's becoming harder for people who don't live as close, and restrictions in different areas and things like that.
But I didn't always attend all the sessions, but I attended some of them.
So how are the restrictions now compared to the beginning of lockdown when we were really fully locked down?
I think they were harder then than they are now.
Although I think there was a time when they were easier than they are now when people were starting to meet up again.
And how have you found it on your wellbeing? How have you felt during all of this?
